Description: A sherd worked into a disk shape tool with a hole drilled in the centre. The edges are notched all round. The sherd comes from a hand-made pottery vessel with a rocker packed dotted zigzag decoration, type R1, and a high grade mineral fabric with few small vegetals, type I. Ware Group B. It may have been used for pottery decorating..
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Nabta Playa, E-91-1 Area C
Curator's comments: References for typology: Gatto, M.C. 2006, The Khartoum Variant Pottery in Context: rethinking the Early and Middle Holocene Nubian Sequence, Archeologie du Nil Moyen 10; Gatto, M.C. 2002, Early Neolithic Pottery of the Nabta-Kiseiba Area: Stylisitic Attributes and Regional Relationships, in K. Nelson 2002, Holocene Settlement of the Egyptian Sahara, vol. 2, the Pottery of Nabta Playa: 65-78.
Discussed and illustrated in Jordeczka, M., et al. 2011, Early Holocene pottery in the Western Desert of Egypt: new data from Nabta Playa. Antiquity 85 (2011): 99–115, fig. 10.1
Bibliographic references: Nelson, Schild & Wendorf 2002 / Holocene Settlement of the Egyptian Sahara, Vol. 2 The Pottery of Nabta Playa (fig. 3.10a)
